Derek and Philip (and others who may have used a similar 
interpretation),

First, anyone else who had this confusion please let me know.  (I'm 
wondering how widespread it is.)

It is probably inevitable that in a fairly large and complicated 
system people will interpret certain things that seem clear to each 
individual in different ways.  Unfortunately this seems to be the 
case here, and I'm sorry about the confusion.

Ultimately, the difference between our two systems is just in the 
rate of adding links and nodes.  That rate is indeed quite different 
(unless you made yours extremely small), but otherwise, both systems 
are still NEAT, so I don't think it's *that* surprising that your 
system still works...it's just pumping more structure in faster. 
Most likely that's a liability and so your current performance can 
be even further improved.  Not necessarily bad news!

Unfortunately, it may explain why you found blended runs to be such 
an advantage, so it may mean further experiments are needed.  Not 
terrible news, though!  It's still interesting to note that high 
rates of structure adding combined with high rates of deletion 
together may come out fairly effective.  However, what we now need 
to know is whether your blending was just compensating for an overly 
aggressive structure building policy, or whether your results 
generalize.

As for the points of ambiguity...

Our EC paper stated:

"In smaller populations, the probability of adding a new node was 
0.03 and the probability of a new link mutation was 0.05. In the 
larger population, the probability of adding a new link was 0.3."

Note that this does not use the term "mutation rate," which you and 
Derek were thinking of.  Note "the probability of adding a link" 
would be a strange way to phrase something that could add more than 
one link.

When we talked about weight mutation, we said:

"There was an 80% chance of a genome having its connection weights 
mutated, in which case each weight had a 90% chance of being 
uniformly perturbed and a 10% chance of being assigned a new random 
value."

Note again, no use of the ambiguous term "mutation rate."  It says 
there is an 80% chance of any genome having its links mutated.

Nevertheless, ambiguity is in the eye of the beholder, and if it was 
ambiguous to you, then that's how it is.   But I am glad now to have 
gotten to the bottom of this.

As for the final question of whether you can add a link and a node 
at the same time, in my system you can't.  However, it would hardly 
make a difference.  What makes a difference is adding big globs of 
structure all at once vs. adding just one or on a rare occasion two 
pieces.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Philip Tucker" <ptucker@g...> wrote:
> > Ah, we may have hit on a reason for some of our disagreements!  
The 
> > add_connection mutation rate is the probability that an 
*individual 
> > genome* might have a single connection added.  In other words, 
in a 
> > population of 100 individuals and a 0.02 rate, you would expect 
to 
> > get on average 2 new connections over the entire population in a 
> > single generation.
> 
> Wow.  Yeah, that's a pretty friggin' big difference!  Weird that 
our 
> results were as similar as they were give such a significant 
> discrpency in implementation.  Of course, doing it our way with 
lower 
> topological mutation rates might wind up doing about the same 
thing 
> anyway.
> 
> So, let me make sure I have this clear: "mutation rate" means 
> something different in the context of topological mutations from 
> weigth mutations, right?  Weight mutation rate is the percentage 
of 
> connection *genes* that will have their weights tweaked.  Add 
> connection and add neuron rates are the percentage of 
*chromosomes* 
> that will be modified.
> 
> I guess we were biologically inspired in our interpretation.  
> Typically, a mutation rate is a function of the genetic material, 
> right?  A given gene has a certain chance of being modified each 
> generation.  And there's nothing stopping 2 mutations from 
occurring 
> in the same individual.
> 
> > In addition, it is also true that only one add connection 
mutation 
> > can happen to a single individual in a generation.
> 
> Can both happen; i.e., can a chromosome have 1 connection and 1 
node 
> added in the same generation?  If so, can the node be added on the 
> new connection, or a connection be added to the new node?
> 
> > It seems to me that your interpetation was that the mutation rate
> > is on a "per empty slot" basis.  That's radically different than 
my 
> > NEAT implementation...interesting though that that works at
> > all...is that how ANJI has been working?
> 
> Indeed it is.  Time for me to go change the API doc ...
> 
> - Philip
